Award.AwardTitle: The Engineering Medical Therapeutic Technologies-Research Experience for Teachers

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for a three year standard award to support a Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering and puter Science Site program at the University of Southern California (USC), entitled, "The Engineering Medical Therapeutic Technologies-Research Experience for Teachers (EMT2-RET)", under the direction of Dr. Mark Humayun.

The vision of the EMT2-RET program, is to leverage the considerable resources of the University of Southern California to create long-term partnerships among world-renowned biomedical engineering and computer science researchers, K-12 teachers in Los Angeles inner-city schools, and community college educators. 6-week program will support the involvement of a total of 30 (10 per year) high school and community college educators in mentored engineering and computer science research focused on medical therapeutic technologies conducted in Viterbi School of Engineering (VSoE) and the Biomimetic MicroElectronic Systems Engineering Research Center (BMES) Laboratories at USC. The coordinated efforts of multidisciplinary research groups offer RET teachers the opportunity to work in laboratories that range from basic science to systems engineering. Additionally, teachers will participate in professional development workshops in engineering and technology, aiding the teachers in the translation of the RET experience into relevant classroom activities, including discovery-based laboaratory exericses that are standards aligned.

The majority of students in the Los Angeles Unified School District, East Los Angeles College, Pasadena City College, Los Angeles City College are from underrepresented minority groups. The RET program will train science teachers from urban schools in biomedical engineering and computer science and, in turn impact the education of their respective students. Students who traditionally have little or no direct connection with STEM will, through the RET teachers, experience the excitement of cutting edge discoveries. In addition, the professional and collegial relationships that develop between the RET teachers and their USC colleagues and the extensive academic year follow-up component of the RET will foster long-term partnerships.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vision of the Engineering Medical Therapeutic Technologies Research Experience for Teachers (EMT2-RET) program is to leverage the considerable resources of the University of Southern California to create long-term partnerships among world-renowned biomedical engineering and computer science researchers, K-12 teachers in Los Angeles inner-city schools, and community college educators.

The EMT2-RET summer program brought knowledge of science and engineering directly to high school and community college educators by involving them in mentored, discovery-based learning experiences in research laboratories focused on engineering medical therapeutic technologies. Additionally, teachers participated in engineering, technology, and pedagogically focused professional development workshops, facilitating the translation of new found knowledge and skills into meaningful and rigorous high school and community college classroom activities that sparked enthusiasm for science, technology, engineering and math, particularly among minority students. Partnering with institutions that primarily serve disadvantaged and minority students helps us achieve both the EMT2-RET and NSF goal of impacting underserved populations in STEM. Participation of the teachers in the EMT2-RET research activities and professional development workshops has provided them the ability to teach engineering concepts and research strategies to their K-14 students.

One of the primary goals of the EMT2-RET is the translation of the teachers’ research experience into curricula that the educators bring back to their respective classrooms. To achieve this objective, weekly professional development workshops which focused on curricular design were led by USC professors and enabled RET teachers to leverage their laboratory experience to make connections to specific grade-level content standards. The EMT2-RET driven curriculum introduces knowledge and skills in science, engineering and computer science into K-14 classroom practice and bridges the divide between university research and K-14 STEM education. Emphasis is placed on the development of hands-on, discovery-oriented classroom lessons as research indicates that one of the most effective and engaging ways to learn science is to do science.

The integration of the teachers into EMT2-RET labs allowed them to directly apply both the scientific method and the engineering design process to cutting-edge research projects. All of the RET teachers report that the summer program helped them better understand the nature and expectations of a university research environment. They are now more aware of the “culture” of the science and engineering communities. Teachers are excited about translating this new knowledge into STEM curricula that introduce their students to the principles and practices of both biomedical engineering and computer science. EMT2-RET-driven curricula will not only impart content knowledge of engineering, but it will also support the development of soft-skills such as effective communication, teamwork, time management, problem-solving, and flexibility and adaptability.

A broader impact of the EMT2-RET program is that students who traditionally have little or no direct connection with STEM professionals will, through the EMT2-RET teachers, be but one degree of separation from world leaders in engineering and computer science and the excitement of cutting edge discoveries. USC faculty and graduate students collaborated with the EMT2-RET teachers to translate their new found science and engineering knowledge and technological skills into age-appropriate, relevant and standards-aligned curricula that encourage participation of K-14 students, particularly underrepresented minority groups, in the biomedical engineering fields. The professional and collegial relationships that developed between the EMT2-RET teachers and their USC colleagues have fostered long-term partnerships. This integration of research and education has enriched the university and K-14 classroom learning environments through the diversity of learning perspectives. Among the community of teachers, students, and school administrators, the University of Southern California’s Engineering Medical Therapeutic Technologies Research Experience for Teachers (EMT2-RET) program has ultimately promoted a broader understanding of the role, relevance and impact of science, engineering, and computer science on health and quality of life issues.
